Graphical abstract In this article, we present a detailed study combining the kinetic studies and in-situ FTIR experiments to investigate the oxidation behavior of chlorobenzene over V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. The catalytic data show the 3–5wt.% V2O5/TiO2 catalysts are best fit for the oxidation of chlorobenzene. The calculated apparent reaction orders are about 0.6 and 0.2, respectively. The results of in-situ FTIR provided mechanism insights into the catalytic reaction, which supports the following proposal: (i) a nucleophilic substitution on VO species and (ii) attacking by surface oxygen through a electrophilic substitution, then (iii) followed by the cracking of ring structure, and further oxidation of the resulting species to form final products. The above results further suggest that the nucleophilic substitution process and surface reaction are kinetically significant steps for chlorobenzene oxidation, determining the overall rate of the reaction. Furthermore, 1,2-dichlorobenzene, 1,3-dichlorobenzene and 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene as additional reactants were tested together with chlorobenzene in binary mixtures to examine their competition reactions. Keywords Catalytic oxidation Chlorobenzene Chlorinated benzenes V2O5/TiO2 FTIR 1 Introduction In China, polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins (PCDDs) and polychlorinated dibenzofurans (PCDFs) known as dioxins, that originated from the incineration of municipal and medical waste are drawing more and more attention [1–4]. Adsorption methods, such as utilizing activated carbon (AC) as adsorbent can reduce PCDD/Fs pollutions effectively, but it can only achieve transferring of contaminants, which need further treatments [5]. Catalytic oxidation is able to decompose the pollutants into CO2, H2O and other small molecules, achieving complete decomposition [6,7]. Therefore, compared with the traditional adsorption methods, employing catalytic oxidation to control dioxins emissions is a more economical and environmentally friendly way. Vanadia-based catalysts have been applied industrially, such as V2O5-WO3/TiO2 and V2O5-MoO3/TiO2, which are commercially employed for the reduction of NO x known as NH3-SCR [8,9]. According to previous reports, these catalysts have been also found to be effective and stable for the destruction of chlorine-containing organic compounds, which allows the simultaneous abatement of PCDD/Fs and NO x from waste incinerators [10–12]. Recently, some authors employed carbonaceous materials to promote the adsorption of pollutants and also O3 was used to further promote dioxins oxidation [13,14]. However, PCDD/Fs are trace organic pollutants with high toxicity, and it is difficult to study the catalytic properties directly in laboratory scale. Therefore, chlorinated benzenes are generally employed for their structural similarity to PCDD/Fs and less toxicity [15–17]. Krishnamoorthy et al. [18] investigated the catalytic oxidation of 1,2-dichlorobenzene over different transition metal oxides and reported that Cr2O3 and V2O5 based catalysts have the highest activity, and TiO2 seems to be the best catalyst support. Bertinchamps et al. [19] studied the catalytic oxidation of benzene over forty different formulations of transition metal oxides based catalysts, and reported similar results. The authors also investigated the effects of a transition metal oxide dopant into V2O5/TiO2 based catalysts toward the catalytic process of chlorobenzene [20]. The catalytic behavior of a reactant is associated with the interaction between the catalyst and the reactant itself. Debecker et al. [21] proposed that the adsorption of furan is significantly different with chlorobenzene, and some of the previously proposed catalyst improvement strategies based on the experiments using chlorobenzene actually prove to be disadvantageous in the removal of PCDD/Fs, which indicates that furan may be a better choice for this purpose [21,22]. Hetrick et al. [23] investigated the adsorption and oxidation of o- and p-chlorophenol over a 3.6wt.% V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, and found the catalyst to be active at temperatures as low as 200°C due to a strong adsorption of these species. Although directly using PCDD/Fs as reactants is quite difficult, some precious data in laboratory scale were still reported [11,13,22]. And it seems that the catalytic behavior of PCDD/Fs is close to furan and chlorophenol. But one should also admit that the concentration of these pollutants varies greatly than that of PCDD/Fs, so the rationality of these species as model reactants is still under debate. The differences between these model reactants and PCDD/Fs mainly include variety of functional groups, number of chlorine substituents, molecular weight and concentration in flue gas. Such differences can directly influence the catalytic behavior that obtained in the laboratory scale [11,21–24]. Under this circumstance, understanding the links between microscopic mechanism and macroscopic phenomenon of model reactants becomes very important. These information can not only give explanations to their own catalytic characteristics, but also provide predictions to catalytic macroscopic behavior of PCDD/Fs, especially when the distinction between model reactants and PCDD/Fs can be analyzed. To the best of our knowledge, such studies are still very few even though V2O5/TiO2 based catalysts has been successfully applied in industrial scale. Therefore, both catalytic (kinetic) studies and in-situ FTIR methods are combined to study the oxidation behavior of chlorobenzene in this paper. V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with different vanadia content were prepared, the changes of surface vanadia species were characterized by X-ray diffraction, Raman and in-situ FTIR measurements, and kinetic parameters of chlorobenzene oxidation were calculated. According to in-situ FTIR experiments, the function of different surface vanadia species was discussed, the transformation of intermediates that formed during catalytic oxidation was studied. Furthermore, 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB), 1,3-dichlorobenzene (m-DCB) and 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene (1,2,4-TCB) as additional reactants were tested together with chlorobenzene in binary mixtures to examine their competition reactions. Hence, these results together give a comprehensive understanding related to adsorption, surface reaction and catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and sample characterization The V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with different vanadia contents (1, 3, 5, 7 and 9wt.%, calculated by the weight percentages of V2O5) were prepared by wet impregnation method. Commercial P25 TiO2 (Degussa, >99.5%; 80% anatase and 20% rutile phases) was calcined at 500°C for 2h. And NH4VO3 (Aladdin, 99.9%) used as V2O5 precursor was heated at 80°C until all NH4VO3 was dissolved. P25 TiO2 was added into NH4VO3 solution, and resulting mixture was stirred for 1h, then all the water was evaporated using a rotary evaporation apparatus. The powder obtained was dried at 110°C overnight, and calcined in air at 500°C for 6h (5°C/min). Catalyst samples are referred to as VTi-1, VTi-3, VTi-5, VTi-7 and VTi-9 for simplicity. The weight percentages of V and Ti were measured by an inductively coupled plasma-optical emitting spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 5300DV, PerkinElmer). The porous texture was characterized by N2 adsorption at 77K in an automatic surface area and porosity analyzer (Autosorb iQ, Quantachrome). The total surface area was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation and the pore volume was determined from the N2 desorption isotherms using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the sample were recorded on a powder diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-RA) using Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 150mA). The Raman spectra were obtained on a Raman spectrometer (Labram aramis, HORIBA Jobin YUvon). The emission line at 514.5nm from an Ar+ laser was focused on the sample under a microscope, and the analyzed spot was 1μm. The time of acquisition was adjusted according to the intensity of the Raman scattering. The wavenumber values reported from the spectra are accurate to within 2cm−1. The XPS measurements were collected on a photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250, Thermo Scientific) using Al Kα (1486.8eV) radiation as the excitation source (powered at 10mA and 15kV). 2.2 Catalytic oxidation of chlorinated benzenes Catalytic evaluations were carried out in a quartz tube, single-pass fixed-bed micro reactor (4mm i.d.) with a sieve plate in the middle. The reactor was heated by an electric furnace, and the temperature was monitored through a K-type thermocouple next to the sieve plate. Chlorinated benzenes were introduced into the reaction flow through a saturator via Ar. The total flow rate of the mixed stream was 100mLmin−1 with 10vol.% O2 (calculated at atmospheric pressure and room temperature). The entire gas path was wrapped with heating belts and heated to 80°C in order to reduce adsorption. The analyses of the reactants and organic products were performed on-line by gas chromatography (GC 7890A, Agilent), which was equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an electron capture detector (ECD). The CO x yields were also determined on-line by gas chromatography (GC-QP2010, Shimadzu), and the detector used was a FID with a methanizer furnace for converting CO x to CH4. The HCl selectivity was analyzed by gas detector tubes of HCl and Cl2 (Cl2 was never observed in this work). The concentrations of chlorinated benzenes in the mixed steam were calibrated through a by-pass (±1%). In a typical run, 100mg of the catalyst (corresponding WHSV of 60,000mLg−1 h−1 and GHSV of 37,500h−1, in the form of 150–180μm) was placed on the sieve plate. The catalyst was treated at 400°C for 1h in a 10% O2/Ar stream, then the catalytic bed temperature was cooled down to 100°C (no conversion was observed) and stabilized for 60min. Subsequently, the catalytic evaluation was carried out with a heating rate of 5°C/min at a temperature gradient of 25–400°C and stabilized until a stead state was achieved (defined as less than 2ppm change in outlet concentration over 30min). The conversion was calculated by the Eq. (1): (1) x = C ( in ) − C ( out ) C ( in ) × 100 % where x is the conversion, C(in) and C(out) are the inlet and outlet concentrations of gas-phase chlorinated benzenes. The blank run (without catalyst), which was performed at 100–340°C, revealed that neither catalytic nor gas-phase homogeneous reactions had occurred. 2.3 Kinetic studies The external diffusion effect was investigated by varying the speed of feed gas while keeping a constant WHSV (60,000mLg−1 h−1). Similarly, the internal diffusion effect was checked by changing the particle size of the catalyst (as shown in Fig. S1). The results showed that the catalytic reaction was operated without diffusional limitation under 12% conversion of chlorobenzene. The kinetic experiments were carried out under differential condition (the maximum conversion was controlled below 8%). And the reaction rate was calculated as follows: (2) − r = F × d x d W ≈ F × x W where −r (molg−1 s−1) is the reaction rate, F (mols−1) is the inlet flow rate, x (%) is the catalytic conversion of chlorobenzene, and W is the catalyst weight (g). 2.4 In-situ FTIR experiments FTIR spectra were collected with a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet 6700, Thermo) equipped with an MCT detector (cooled by liquid nitrogen) and a stainless steel IR cell (CaF2 windows). Prior to all experiments, the IR cell was flushed by flowing Ar to ensure that it was clean. Then the powder sample (about 50mg) was pressed into a self-supported disk (approximately 8mm in diameter) and oxidized at 400°C for 1h in a 10% O2/Ar stream. After this process, the sample was cooled down to desired temperature in flowing Ar or a 10% O2/Ar stream depending on the next operation condition. In order to examine the strength of adsorption and the reactivity of the different surface species, the spectra of clean powder sample surface were collected as the background in flowing Ar. Then a chlorobenzene/Ar stream was introduced into IR cell followed by exposure the surface species to flowing Ar. Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) method was carried out to investigate the interactions between surface intermediates and catalyst at different temperature. The backgrounds were collected during the cooling process at each evaluated temperature (stable condition) in a 10% O2/Ar stream. Then a chlorobenzene/10% O2/Ar stream was introduced into the IR cell at 200°C. Subsequently, the catalyst was treated in flowing Ar or 10% O2/Ar (30min) followed heating at a giving temperature ramp (10°C/min) and holding 5min at each 50°C increment. The IR spectra were collected at the end of each step. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization V2O5 content, specific surface area and calculated VO x surface density (ns ) are shown in Table 1 . It can be clearly observed that S BET decreases with the increase of V2O5 content, but the effect is little even at a relatively high V2O5 content (above 5wt.%). Based on the ns calculated from V2O5 content and S BET, vanadia species on VTi-1 is under theoretical monovanadate (<2.3 VO x /nm2), VTi-7 and VTi-9 are above theoretical polyvanadate (>7.5 VO x /nm2), VTi-3 and VTi-5 is between two states [25,26]. Wide angle XRD patterns of P25 TiO2 and V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with different V2O5 content are shown in Fig. 1 . The weak peaks of V2O5 show on V2O5/TiO2 catalysts when increasing V2O5 content to 7wt.%, suggesting that microcrystalline V2O5 is formed. No obvious change can be observed in the relative intensity of the diffraction peaks when comparing the anatase and rutile phases, thus confirming that the support is stable in the process of preparation. The structure of vanadia species was analyzed by Raman as shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2, a sharp band at 993cm−1 can be assigned to crystalline V2O5. Bands around 1030cm−1 and a at 1016cm−1 gradually emerges with the increasing of vanadia loading can be assigned to VO species, the former occurs predominantly as isolated monovanadates [27,28], while the latter occurs in this region can be assigned to corresponding mode of dispersed polyvanadates [28]. The presence of the broad band at 910–930cm−1 can be also assigned to polyvanadates [28–30]. It should be noted that the band at 993cm−1 slightly emerges in the spectra of VTi-5, suggesting that microcrystalline V2O5 have already been formed although being undetected by XRD analysis. And this band grows sharply with increasing vanadia loading, indicating that a large amount of microcrystalline V2O5 has been formed on the catalyst surface. The bands assigned to VO species are too weak to be observed in the spectra of VTi-1 and VTi-3, which is inconsistent with their VO x surface density. However, the in-situ FTIR characterization exhibits clear band that is assigned to VO species [8] (as shown in Fig. S2). So such phenomenon may be caused by hydroxylation of the catalyst surface in ambient condition during Raman characterization. 3.2 Catalytic and kinetic studies Chlorobenzene conversions over P25 TiO2 and V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with different vanadia contents are shown as functions of temperature in Fig. 3 a. The results disclose that the conversions of chlorobenzene for this set decreases in the following order, VTi-5>VTi-7>VTi-9>VTi-3>VTi-1>P25 TiO2. But the activity performance is very close among the 5–9wt.% V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with microcrystalline V2O5. Schimmoeller et al. [31] studied catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene over flame-made V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with high vanadia content (up to 19.5%). The results revealed that polymeric VO x species sitting directly on the support is more active than monomeric VO x species and crystalline species depart from TiO2 support. Therefore, the above results indicate that vanadia should be kept below the maximum monolayer for practical application. Besides, although VTi-1 has a large increase for the catalytic activity than TiO2 support, it seems still necessary to increase vanadia loading to 3wt.%. Additionally, no deactivation was observed during the catalytic tests (Fig. S3 and Table S1), which shows good stability of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 3b presents the data of final CO and CO2 yields together with HCl selectivity during the oxidation of chlorobenzene over VTi-3. As shown in Fig. 3b, the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene over VTi-3 gives rise to CO/CO2 mixture rich in CO, and the selectivity to HCl is always 100%. Besides, no chlorinated benzenes with higher chlorination degrees were detected (Fig. S4) [21,24,32], indicating V2O5/TiO2 catalysts is quite suitable for the oxidation of chlorobenzene [33]. Fig. 4 shows chlorobenzene conversions as functions of temperature over VTi-3 under different inlet chlorobenzene and oxygen concentrations. As indicated in Fig. 4a, the conversions of chlorobenzene decrease with the increase of chlorobenzene concentration. However, the complete conversion still can be achieved at 400°C for various concentrations of chlorobenzene. Observed T 50 (the temperature of 50% conversion) changes from 275°C to 302°C (corresponding to the chlorobenzene concentrations of 300ppm and 2000ppm, respectively). In Fig. 4b, it can be found that the conversions of chlorobenzene increase with the increase of oxygen concentration. And the observed T 50 changes only form 306°C to 277°C (corresponding to the oxygen concentrations of 2% and 20%, respectively). These data illustrate that both the inlet concentration of chlorobenzene and oxygen are not very sensitive parameters. To gain further insight in this issue, kinetic studies were carried out by investigating the effect of inlet chlorobenzene and oxygen concentrations on the reaction rate (−r) as shown in Fig. 5 . The conversions were controlled below 8% to obtain initial reaction rates for all conditions. It was found that all the data could be explained by the power rate law equation as follow: (3) − r = k C chlorobenzene m C O 2 n where k is the kinetic constant, C chlorobenzene (molNm−3) is the inlet chlorobenzene concentration, C O 2 (molNm−3) is the O2 concentration, n and m are the apparent reaction orders of chlorobenzene and oxygen, respectively. The values of n and m are obtained from the slope of each line in Fig. 5b and d. As one can see in Fig. 5a, the reaction rate grows nonlinearly with the increase of chlorobenzene concentration in the studied temperature range. In Fig. 5c, a similar tendency can be concluded, but the growth of the reaction rate seems to be more slowly with the increase of oxygen concentration. Indeed, compared with the average value of m, the average value of n is much lower (Table 2 ). These data are interesting. In particular, the reaction order of chlorobenzene is roughly close to first-order, indicating that the adsorption of chlorobenzene on catalyst surface is difficult. In contrast, strong adsorption results apparent zero-order for reactants, because all the active sites are occupied. For oxygen as one of the reactants, the reaction order is approximate zero-order. It can be assumed that if the intermediates could directly react with gas-phase oxygen, the apparent reaction order of oxygen would be close to first-order, thus indicating that chlorobenzene molecular may not directly react with gas-phase oxygen. Based on the Arrhenius equation, the apparent activation energy (E a) is also obtained, which is similar to previously reported values [34,35]. 3.3 In-situ FTIR experiments The kinetic results disclose an important feature of the catalytic reaction, which is the apparent reaction order of chlorobenzene or oxygen is between zero- and first-order. However, kinetic method tends to be a general approach, it still cannot explain the mechanism insights directly. For instance, the understanding with respect to active sites, oxidation intermediates or significant steps of the catalytic reaction need more direct tools. Therefore, in-situ FTIR method was used in this section to study the mechanism on the interaction between chlorobenzene molecule and V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. Accordingly, In-situ FTIR spectra of the surface species during adsorption and desorption of chlorobenzene over VTi-5 and P25 TiO2 were conducted at 100°C (gas-phase oxygen was excluded) and shown in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6, bands at 1581, 1478 and 1444cm−1 can be assigned to CC vibration of adsorbed chlorobenzene [36], and these bands can be observed both on the spectra of VTi-5 and TiO2 support during the adsorption. Through the catalytical evaluation, it was found that no macro conversion for chlorobenzene at 100°C over all the studied samples. However, some new bands that obviously do not belong to chlorobenzene can be observed on the spectra of VTi-5, which is similar with the results in the presence of gas-phase oxygen we have previously reported [24]. To be specific, bands at 1572, 1482cm−1 (CC stretching vibration), 1248cm−1 (CH in plane vibration) and 1216cm−1 (CO stretching vibration) can be assigned to a surface phenolate species [37–40], a band at 1633cm−1 can be assigned to a surface catecholate or quinolate species due to further oxidation of phenolates [41], and bands at 1680 and 1660cm−1 emerging in the traditional CO stretching vibration region can be assigned to o- and p-benzoquinone-type species [39,41], respectively. A surface chlorinated acetates species with non-cyclic structure also can be identified by its characteristic bands at 1561cm−1 (asymmetric stretching vibration of COO− [15]) and 1372cm−1 (CH2 stretching vibration [42]), indicating that benzene ring has already been cracked at low temperature even no final products being detected. In contrast, only adsorbed chlorobenzene (1581, 1478 and 1444cm−1) can be observed on TiO2 surface during the adsorption, suggesting that vanadia plays a key role for the activation of chlorobenzene molecular. After exposure of the adsorbed species in flowing Ar, the bands that assigned to adsorbed chlorobenzene (1581, 1478 and 1444cm−1) disappear, while the bands that assigned to the intermediates seems to be very stable in such condition. This phenomenon indicates that these intermediates were chemisorbed on the catalyst surface. As for vanadia species, a reverse band at 2040cm−1 can be assigned to the overtone vibration of VO species [8], and this state indicates that VO species was occupied during the adsorption and desorption process. Reverse bands at 3636 and 3652cm−1 can be assigned to VOH species [8], but these bands gradually recover from a reverse status to normal during the desorption, suggesting a removal of adsorbed species. Thus, the state changes of vanadia species can be related to the behavior of adsorbed species during the exposure to flowing Ar. It can be deduced that the intermediates which cannot be removed in flowing Ar are most probably formed on VO sites, while chlorobenzene molecules that adsorbed on VOH sites tend to keep their initial form instead of undergoing chemical changes, thus being easily separated. The changes on the TiO2 support is relatively simple, a sharp band at 1621cm−1 together with reverse bands at 3720, 3690, 3670 and 3648cm−1 that can be assigned to TiOH species was formed during the adsorption of chlorobenzene [36]. However, these bands are not recovered after the removal of chlorobenzene, instead the intensity of these bands still increase. So TiO2 surface seemed go through a continuous process of dehydroxylation whether chlorobenzene was present or not. Thus, the band at 1620cm−1 can be attributed to the changes of TiOH species. The band at 1606cm−1 seems having a similar trend during the desorption process on VTi-5, but the change is not significant. This band can be attributed to the changes of VOH species (relatively minor). Through the analysis of intermediates, it can be found that the phenolate species has the most similar structure compared with chlorobenzene molecular. In this case, the lattice oxygen of VO species can be responsible for the formation of the phenolate species through a nucleophilic substitution of CCl bond (CCl bond is weaker than CH bond). As a result, a COV structure is formed as the first step of the catalytic reaction. The benzene ring is then attacked by reactive oxygen species through electrophilic substitution leading the formation of benzoquinone-type species. As the continuous attacking, the ring structure will be broken causing the formation of non-cyclic species. It must be pointed out that the only reason for the employing VTi-5 during the above experiment is these chemisorbed species were not observed on the samples with lower vanadia loadings, and the reason is still unclear. It is speculated that the nucleophilic substitution that occurred on isolated monovanadates was weak [31]. However further work need to be done to confirm the speculation, which is presently under study in our laboratory. For studying the role of oxygen (gas-phase and surface) and investigating the whole catalytic process of chlorobenzene, TPSR method was employed to observe the changes of surface species. And in-situ FTIR spectra of VTi-3 collected during TPSR process with/without gas-phase oxygen are shown in Figs. 7 and 8 . In Fig. 7a, new bands at 1528 and 1536cm−1 can be assigned to a surface maleate species [15,43,44], and the characteristic bands gradually shift to 1515cm−1 with the reduction of the surface concentration of these species [24]. A new band at 1418cm−1 (asymmetric stretching vibration of COO− [15]) which may be too weak to be observed at 100°C can also be assigned to acetates, and a series of bands at 1875, 1835, 1790 and 1746cm−1 can be assigned to a surface aldehyde species [15,41,42]. Besides, bands at 1653 and 1614cm−1 can be assigned to chloroacetyl chloride species [15]. The strong intensity of bands that are assigned to chlorinated species suggest that interaction between surface chlorine and intermediates occurs. After exposure the adsorbed species in a 10% O2/Ar stream, the intensity of all bands decreases especially the band at 1216cm−1 (surface phenolates). However, the decrement seems very little, which is understandable since the catalytic capacity of VTi-3 for chlorobenzene is relatively low at 200°C after all. With the increase of temperature, the intensity of these bands decreases rapidly (Fig. 7b–f). It should be pointed out that, no obvious organic by-products were found during the catalytic evaluations. Although some previous reports found (chloro)-maleic anhydrides as by-products during the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene, the amount of these species is quite low [21,32]. Hence, the phenomenon suggests a fast decomposition of the intermediates. To be specific, the band of phenolates (1216cm−1) disappears in the temperature range of 250–300°C, the band of o-benzoquinone-type species (1680cm−1) disappears at 250°C, characteristic bands of aldehydes (1875, 1835, 1790 and 1746cm−1) disappear at 350°C. In contrast, only the bands that assigned to p-benzoquinone-type species (1660cm−1), maleates (1528–1515, 1436 and 1312cm−1) and chlorinated acetates (1461, 1418 and 1372cm−1) still can be observed at 400°C, indicating that these species are more stable on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 8, the changes of the surface phenolate, catecholate and quinolate species in flowing Ar seems to be similar to that in presence of oxygen, but the intensity of the bands that assigned to surface maleates and chlorinated acetates resulting from the cracking of ring structure seems to be increased. And with the process of the temperature program, it can be observed that a similar changing process of the surface intermediates occurs, except that the intensity of the bands that assigned to surface maleates decreases more slowly than that assigned to other species (Fig. 8b–f). This clearly shows that surface oxygen and bulk oxygen can participate into the catalytic reaction in absence of gas-phase oxygen, indicating the Mas & van Krevelen mechanism does being evoked during the oxidation of chlorobenzene. However, one should notice that although the overall trend is similar, but the oxidation process become more slowly than that in presence of gas-phase oxygen, especially in the temperature range of 200–300°C (Fig. 8b–d). Hence, kinetic studies and in-situ FTIR results indicate that surface intermediates are more inclined to react with surface oxygen and bulk oxygen, and gas-phase oxygen can supply their consumption, thus accelerating the surface oxidation process. Through summarizing the results of in-situ FTIR experiments, we propose a reaction mechanism as shown in Fig. 9 . Chlorobenzene molecular (A) goes through a nucleophilic substitution of CCl bond on VO species to form a surface phenolate species (B). And then it will be attacked by reactive oxygen species through an electrophilic substitution to form a surface catecholate (C) or quinolate species (D). Subsequently, the fracture of ring structure occurs and further oxidation of the resulting surface maleates (E), chlorinated acetates (F) and chloroacetyl chloride (G) species to form final products. The surface chlorine species can be removed by surface intermediates (or H2O). The active site is then re-oxidized to the initial state, so that a complete catalytic cycle is finished. Besides, the desorption of CO, CO2 and HCl as final products is supposed to be very quick, which is evident that no bands assigned to these species can be observed. At relative low temperature, a significant amount of chlorobenzene retain their original form instead of being transformed (Fig. 6). In contrast, the chemisorption of chlorinated phenols through their hydroxyl group is very easy [23], and the complete conversion temperature of chlorinated phenols is around 200°C. And the surface intermediates still exist in a broad temperature range (200–400°C) on the catalyst surface even without the presence of chlorobenzene (Figs. 7 and 8), thus the oxidation of surface intermediates is quite difficult. Hence, we suggest that the nucleophilic substitution and surface reaction processes are kinetically significant steps. 3.4 Bi-components competition reactions In practical, there are many kinds of organic pollutants in flue gas [45], and these species will compete over active sites during the catalytic reactions. Because of the complexity of a practical system, it is too unrealistic to study all these species at the same time. Hence, in this part we mainly focus on the reaction characteristics when the system involves binary mixtures. Although the oxidation behavior of oxygenated species (furan or PCDD/Fs) seems being very different with these oxygen-free ones [21,22], the experiments in this section may deduce the effects of chlorine substituents and molecular weight (internal diffusion) in mixture, which is closer to the real catalytic reaction process than reacting separately. Therefore, o-DCB, m-DCB and 1,2,4-TCB were introduced as additive components to study their competition reactions. It is known that the polarity of chlorinated benzenes increases with the increase of chlorination degree, while the dissociation energy of CCl bonds are quite similar [46]. So the apparent phenomena of multicomponent reactions can deduce the possible reaction mechanism. In the experiment, we kept the total concentration of organic species and oxygen to be constant, and the concentration of different organic compounds equally with each other. Fig. 10 shows the results of the competition reactions. As one can see, the introducing of chlorinated benzenes with higher chlorination degrees results an overall decrease of the conversions for these with relatively lower chlorination degrees. And an opposite trend can be observed for the former ones. There are several explanations for such phenomena. One is that polychlorinated benzenes tend to adsorb faster and stronger than monochlorobenzene because they are heavier. And on the other hand dichlorobenzenes offer two and 1,2,4-TCB offers three CCl bonds with similar dissociation energy, which is more easy for the nucleophilic substitution. The above phenomena show the degree of chlorination of chlorinated benzene has not just impact on the oxidation of itself, but also affect the catalytic behavior of other species that are introduced into the reaction system. In our previous study, it is found that the increase of chlorination degree for chlorinated benzene can increase the difficulty for oxygen species attacking due to electron-withdrawing effect of chlorine toward the aromatic ring system, and lead to decreasing of reaction rate by the increase of surface chlorine [24]. In the competition reactions, the reaction rate of an individual reactant equals to the rate of “activated adsorption” step in a constant reaction status. So the electron-withdrawing effect is irrelevant to the above phenomena, and the reaction rate can be assumed totally depending on the rate of the nucleophilic substitution step of each reactant, respectively. Besides, the amount of the introduced chlorine were supposedly reduced when a low degree of chlorination of chlorinated benzene was introduced. Thus, the above reasons lead to a promoting effect for dichlorobenzenes and 1,2,4-TCB, while a deactivating effect toward chlorobenzene occurs. This trend is relatively obvious during the oxidation of the chlorobenzene and 1,2,4-TCB mixture. In Fig. 10c, the conversions of 1,2,4-TCB are always lower than that of chlorobenzene in a separate condition, but the conversions of 1,2,4-TCB in the binary mixture is even higher than that of chlorobenzene oxidized alone in the temperature range of 150–250°C. However, it should be also noticed that the overall conversions of dichlorobenzenes and 1,2,4-TCB are still lower than chlorobenzene in those binary reactions, especially in the temperature range of 275–400°C. In the binary systems, both the molecular diameter and molecular weight of chlorinated benzenes increase with the increase of chlorination degree, hence the oxidation of dichlorobenzenes and 1,2,4-TCB can be affected by more serious internal diffusion than chlorobenzene (see Fig. S1) in the high temperature range (surface reaction is quite fast). And it is likely to affect the finally conversions of chlorinated benzenes that studied, because active sites can be more occupied by the species that has lower degree of influence by internal diffusion. Therefore, in the low temperature range (i.e., <225°C), chlorinated benzenes with higher chlorination degree can react easily with the catalyst, thus having advantages in the competitive reaction. However, in high temperature range (i.e., >275°C), the diffusion effect dominates, and the oxidation of these species is suppressed. 4 Conclusion A series of V2O5/TiO2 catalysts with different vanadia content were synthesized and characterized by XRD, Raman and in-situ FTIR. The catalytic results of these catalysts confirm the widely spread notion, that it is meaningless to increase vanadia content upon maximum monolayer for the oxidation of chlorobenzene. An apparent 0.6 order reaction for chlorobenzene and 0.2 order reaction for oxygen were obtained. Based on these results together with the in-situ FTIR experiments, it is proposed that that the nucleophilic substitution of CCl bond and surface reaction of the resulted intermediates are kinetically significant steps for chlorobenzene oxidation, determining the overall rate of reaction. And the absence of gas-phase oxygen showed limited impact to the oxidation of surface intermediates compared with the normal reaction condition during TPSR process, thus proving that surface oxygen is involved in the oxidation process. During the competition reactions, the introducing of chlorobenzenes with higher chlorination degree results an overall decrease of the conversions for these with relatively lower chlorination degree. And an opposite trend can be observed for the former ones. These phenomena suggest that polychlorinated benzenes react more easily with the catalyst through nucleophilic substitution, thus having advantages in the intrinsic competitive reaction. However, the conversions of these species are always lower than that of chlorobenzene in high temperature range (≥275°C) regardless of the reaction conditions, indicating that the total reaction rates of polychlorinated benzenes may significantly affected by internal diffusion. coredata.dc:description: In this article, we present a detailed study combining the kinetic studies and in-situ FTIR experiments to investigate the oxidation behavior of chlorobenzene over V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. The catalytic data show the 3–5wt.% V2O5/TiO2 catalysts are best fit for the oxidation of chlorobenzene. The calculated apparent reaction orders are about 0.6 and 0.2, respectively. The results of in-situ FTIR provided mechanism insights into the catalytic reaction, which supports the following proposal: (i) a nucleophilic substitution on VO species and (ii) attacking by surface oxygen through a electrophilic substitution, then (iii) followed by the cracking of ring structure, and further oxidation of the resulting species to form final products. The above results further suggest that the nucleophilic substitution process and surface reaction are kinetically significant steps for chlorobenzene oxidation, determining the overall rate of the reaction. Furthermore, 1,2-dichlorobenzene, 1,3-dichlorobenzene and 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene as additional reactants were tested together with chlorobenzene in binary mixtures to examine their competition reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics and mechanism study on catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene over V2O5/TiO2 catalysts
